intro: Brachyotum rostratum, commonly known as the rostrated brachyotum, is a flowering plant native to certain regions of South America. It belongs to the family Malvaceae, which includes cotton and hibiscus. The plant is characterized by its distinctive, elongated bracts that resemble a beak, giving it its common name. Its flowers are typically yellow or orange and are clustered in inflorescences. Brachyotum rostratum is often found in dry, open habitats and is adapted to thrive in arid conditions.
